stream_context.summary: Kaze reviews and begins integrating a massive graphical and geometrical rework of the Ghost Ship level (Course 5) submitted by artist Biobak. The stream is dominated by Kaze reading Biobak's changelog, reacting to the new models, and performing a lengthy debugging session to fix crashes and rendering errors caused by the new assets. He also briefly shows a new Saloon level and provides feedback on a music track for it from composer Badub.

development_findings.summary: A new saloon level features a jail cell that will visually fill up with captured outlaws as the player progresses, providing a dynamic world state.
development_findings.quote: Every time you catch an outlaw the outlaw will be in here so this jail cell slowly fills up as you collect stars which i think is even better.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to make the ship's plank a bouncy diving board, rewarding players with a high jump for a potential secret (Yoshi Coin) and creating an intentional shortcut.
development_findings.quote: Add a bouncy diving board. Maybe it has a Yoshi coin if you ground pound on it and jump very high question mark. I think that would look very cool... Have it also be working as a shortcut up to the rope.

development_findings.summary: A treasure map in the ghost ship's captain's quarters is planned to be an easter egg, hinting at the location of another level, the Ice Capital.
development_findings.quote: The pirate map in tourist 5 should mark a location that Corresponds The ice caps Entrance. Doesn't need to be a perfect hint just a neat reference.

development_findings.summary: Biobak's redesign of the crumbling floor room requires Kaze to completely reprogram the falling tile behavior to match the new square tile layout.
development_findings.quote: I'll have to make a lot of programming changes here because this is going to be a completely new layout, but it shouldn't be an issue.

development_findings.summary: Kaze identifies a problem with Biobak's sea-to-sky transition and devises a more technical solution using the skybox, color fades, and view space manipulation to achieve a seamless effect with the moving water.
development_findings.quote: The problem with this is that these waves are gonna go up and down, so this transition here is gonna... the waves are gonna go through it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze explains a core N64 technical limitation: a vertex cannot have both a color and a normal for lighting simultaneously. He must rework materials Biobak created to be compatible with this constraint.
development_findings.quote: The vertices only store either vertex color or the direction the vertex is facing. So if you already have one, you can have the other.

development_findings.summary: After a lengthy debugging session, Kaze determines that the game crash was caused by animated texture scripts ('Detect Channels') referencing outdated geometry from before Biobak's rework.
development_findings.quote: Yeah, okay. It was Detect Channels. We need to remake the texture animations. That's what's going on here.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong dislike for paintings and the convention of them representing all art.
context_findings.quote: I don't like that paintings are synonymous with art. I think that's stupid. I don't like paintings at all. I'm a painting hater.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes professional programmers are often overpaid and underworked, citing the phenomenon of 'over-employment' where they take on multiple jobs without anyone noticing.
context_findings.quote: I think programmers in a 35 hour work week, they just work 10 hours. I feel like programmers are the laziest people on the planet.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to release the entire project, including his custom engine, as open source upon the game's completion.
context_findings.quote: When I release this hack my engine will be public. I'll make the hack open source like all of it at the same time.

context_findings.summary: Kaze explains that the game intentionally lacks a 'clear color' (a skybox-like background color) because the operation is too performance-intensive on the N64, consuming 10% of a frame's render time.
context_findings.quote: Applying the clear color takes around three milliseconds which is like 10 percent of the render time of a frame. So doing a clear color is gonna be very very expensive for you at 64.

context_findings.summary: Kaze articulates his puzzle design philosophy: puzzles should showcase interesting mechanics to the player rather than being intentionally difficult or obscure.
context_findings.quote: This is not good because this is a hard puzzle to figure out. This is good because we are showing a cool idea to the player, and the player is like, oh, that's neat. My brain is expanding. So it doesn't need to be difficult.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a preference for older operating systems like Windows 7, citing concerns about spyware in newer versions like Windows 11.
context_findings.quote: I would still be using windows 7 if it was a viable option.

context_findings.summary: Kaze briefly speculates on whether Nintendo views modding as a potential competitor to their game development pipeline.

biobak.summary: Biobak delivered a massive, comprehensive rework of the entire ghost ship level (Course 5), including the exterior, interior rooms, textures, lighting, and geometry.
biobak.quote: Dude, you updated fucking everything. Nothing's the same in here.

biobak.summary: Biobak's changelog, read by Kaze, details specific updates like revamping the library, adding a pushable shelf puzzle, creating a new captain's quarters, and redesigning numerous rooms.
biobak.quote: Fucked up the carpet. This combiner should work I think.

biobak.summary: Kaze expresses significant admiration for the quality and detail of Biobak's modeling and texture work throughout the stream.
biobak.quote: You remapped the cannon stance like a fucking work of art.

biobak.summary: Kaze identifies and fixes several technical issues in Biobak's model related to N64 rendering limitations, such as incorrect texture formats, layer assignments, and material properties that don't work on original hardware.
biobak.quote: Oh, Biobak loves doing this. I'll just cut the camera to the doors.

badub.summary: Badub submitted a new music track for the saloon level. Kaze provided feedback that it was too upbeat and similar to a previous track.
badub.quote: It's a nice song, but it doesn't quite have the vibe I'm looking for. And it's too much like the zoo song.

badub.summary: After receiving feedback, Badub immediately agreed and began reworking the saloon music to better fit the desired vibe.
badub.quote: Oh, he says he's changing it. Nice.

zeina.summary: Zeina is mentioned as having worked on something the previous week, but no specific details about her animation contributions are discussed in this stream.
zeina.quote: Zayn i tried to zayn i just scrubbed last week the hell how are you doing this

key_stories.title: The Ghost Ship Rework and Integration
key_stories.summary: Biobak delivered a massive, surprise rework of the entire ghost ship level. Kaze's initial excitement turned into a lengthy technical session of reviewing the changes, integrating the new assets, and debugging the numerous crashes and rendering issues caused by the new model's incompatibility with the N64's rendering pipeline.
key_stories.challenge: The existing ghost ship level (Course 5), made three years prior, looked dated and inconsistent with the project's evolving quality standards.
key_stories.process: Biobak, the artist, completely redesigned and remodeled the entire level, both exterior and interior. He provided a detailed changelog which Kaze read on stream. Kaze then began the process of importing the new model, identifying technical incompatibilities (texture formats, layer sorting, material settings), and debugging a critical crash.
key_stories.outcome: The level is visually stunning and full of creative new ideas, but the imported model is incompatible with the N64 engine, causing crashes and rendering errors that Kaze must spend the rest of the stream debugging and fixing.
key_stories.key_quote: Holy shit, everything is different. How did he do it?

key_stories.title: Debugging the Level Crash
key_stories.summary: A game-breaking crash occurred after importing the new ghost ship model. Kaze undertook a methodical debugging process, removing categories of objects one by one to isolate the cause. He eventually discovered the crash was due to old texture animation scripts referencing non-existent geometry from the previous version of the level.
key_stories.challenge: After importing Biobak's new ghost ship model, the game would immediately crash upon loading the level.
key_stories.process: Kaze used a debugging emulator and a process of elimination. He systematically removed different types of objects from the level file—lightning effects, moving crates, enemies, and coin formations—and recompiled the game after each change to see if the crash persisted. After many failed attempts, he correctly deduced the issue was with texture animations.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully identified that the 'Detect Channels' scripts, which handle texture animations, were causing the crash. They were referencing vertex data from the old level geometry, which no longer existed, leading to an error. With the cause identified, he could begin reprogramming them.
key_stories.key_quote: How do any of these cause a crash from just changing the level geometry? That's the crazy part here.

key_stories.title: Saloon Music Feedback Loop
key_stories.summary: The composer, Badub, submitted a new song for the saloon level. Kaze reviewed it and provided direct, constructive feedback that it didn't fit the 'vibe' and was too similar to existing music. Badub was receptive and began working on a revision.
key_stories.challenge: The new saloon level needed a fitting music track.
key_stories.process: Badub, the composer, created and sent a new song to Kaze. Kaze listened to it live on stream, immediately identified that it was too upbeat and sounded too similar to another level's theme, and sent his feedback to Badub.
key_stories.outcome: Badub acknowledged the feedback and agreed to revise the track, demonstrating a smooth and effective collaborative loop between the project lead and the composer.
key_stories.key_quote: It's a nice song, but it doesn't quite have the vibe I'm looking for. And it's too much like the zoo song.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions that his wife, Zeina, 'scrubbed last week' but provides no further details on her work.
questions: What are Zeina's specific animation contributions to the project?
How do you two manage the dynamic of being married while also being key collaborators on a major project?
Can you describe your collaborative process? How does feedback flow between you?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions multiple times that he is using his own custom, optimized version of the SM64 engine, which he plans to release publicly later.
questions: What were the biggest limitations of the public decompilation project that led you to create your own engine fork?
What are the most significant technical achievements or optimizations in 'libsuper'?
How has building your own engine enabled design possibilities that wouldn't have been feasible otherwise?

open_questions.topic: Relationship with Nintendo and Legal Concerns
open_questions.context: Kaze and chat briefly speculate on Nintendo's stance towards the modding community, wondering if they see it as a threat to their developer pipeline.
questions: How does the possibility of legal action from Nintendo influence your development process, if at all?
Have you ever had any direct or indirect contact from Nintendo regarding your work?
What is your personal philosophy on the relationship between fan creators and the original IP holders?

open_questions.context: Kaze and Biobak discuss making a puzzle involving a pushable bookshelf more obvious, with Kaze stating that puzzles should be about showing a cool idea, not being difficult.
questions: Could you elaborate on your philosophy of puzzle design? How do you balance challenge with showcasing mechanics?
Biobak, how do you approach designing a 3D space that communicates a puzzle's solution visually?
Can you walk us through another example of a puzzle in the game and how it evolved based on this philosophy?

open_questions.context: Kaze provides very specific, technical feedback on Badub's music submission for the saloon level.
questions: Badub, what is your creative process for composing a track for a level you may have only seen concept art for?
How does Kaze typically communicate the 'vibe' he's looking for in a piece of music?
How do you handle feedback that requires a significant change or a complete restart on a track?
